title: 109_s265
content: The Act may be cited as the "Trauma Care Systems Planning and Development Act of 2005". Congress finds that there is a history of cooperation between the Federal Government and State governments in developing emergency medical services. Trauma is a leading cause of death in the US, with significant costs associated with traumatic injuries, especially from motor vehicle-related incidents. Improving trauma care systems can reduce deaths from trauma and is crucial for homeland defense. Barriers to prompt emergency medical services exist in the US. Improving trauma care systems is crucial for homeland defense. Amendments are needed to address barriers to prompt emergency medical services in the US. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act aim to improve trauma care systems by collecting and disseminating information on achievements and challenges faced by State and local agencies in providing emergency medical services, with special consideration for rural areas. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act aim to enhance each State's trauma care capabilities and promote consistent collection of trauma data. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include establishing a Clearinghouse on Trauma Care and Emergency Medical Services, redesignating sections, and improving trauma care in rural areas by adding advanced trauma life support to model curricula. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act involve increasing communication and coordination with State trauma systems and requiring matching funds for subsequent fiscal years. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act require matching funds for subsequent fiscal years, with specific ratios for the fourth and fifth years of payments to the State. Subsection (b) is also modified to streamline the requirements. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include changes to subsection (a) regarding nationally recognized standards, evaluation procedures, and data collection requirements in consultation with medical specialty groups. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act involve coordinating trauma system planning with state disaster emergency and bioterrorism hospital planning. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act involve disaster emergency planning, bioterrorism hospital preparedness, and updating guidelines for optimal patient care. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act involve updating the model plan and submission requirements for trauma plans. The restrictions on the use of payments are also revised, along with new reporting requirements by states. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include new reporting requirements by states. The Public Health Service Act is amended to update reporting requirements and funding allocations for fiscal years 2005 to 2009. The Public Health Service Act is amended to update reporting requirements and funding allocations for fiscal years 2005 to 2009. Part E includes miscellaneous programs and a new section is added for an Institute of Medicine study. The Secretary will contract the Institute of Medicine to conduct a study on trauma care and research, evaluating its effectiveness and identifying priorities, especially for high-risk groups. The Secretary will contract the Institute of Medicine to conduct a study on trauma care and research, evaluating its effectiveness and identifying priorities, especially for high-risk groups. The study will identify obstacles to trauma systems development, evaluate alternative strategies for trauma care organization, financing, and delivery, and assess the role of trauma systems in preparedness for mass casualties. A report containing the study results must be submitted to Congress within 2 years, with an authorization of $750,000 for fiscal years 2005 and 2006. Residency training programs in emergency medicine will also be addressed. Section 1251(c) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to change the years referenced. Section 1252 is amended to remove "demonstration" from the section heading. Section 1261 is amended to focus on basic and clinical research on trauma, including prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of trauma-related injuries. The Director will establish a plan for the Program based on recommendations from the NIH Trauma Research Task Force. Changes include updating terminology from "acute head injury" to "traumatic brain injury" and "head" to "traumatic." Subsection (g) is removed, and subsections (h) and (i) are redesignated as (g) and (h) with a change in years from 2001-2005 to 2005-2009. The Director will update terminology and make changes to subsections, including adjusting the years from 2001-2005 to 2005-2009.
